segment.source: Links the value of a property in a control template to the value of some other exposed property on the templated control.
segment.target: Links the value of a property in a control template to the value of some other exposed property on the templated control.

segment.source: TemplateBinding can only be used within a ControlTemplate definition in XAML.
segment.target: TemplateBinding can only be used within a ControlTemplate definition in XAML.

segment.target: {TemplateBinding} markup extension

segment.source: Links the value of a property in a control template to the value of some other exposed property on the templated control.
segment.target: Links the value of a property in a control template to the value of some other exposed property on the templated control.

segment.source: TemplateBinding can only be used within a ControlTemplate definition in XAML.
segment.target: TemplateBinding can only be used within a ControlTemplate definition in XAML.

segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.target: XAML values

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: propertyName
segment.target: propertyName

segment.source: The name of the property being set in the setter syntax.
segment.target: The name of the property being set in the setter syntax.

segment.source: This must be a dependency property.
segment.target: This must be a dependency property.

segment.source: sourceProperty
segment.target: sourceProperty

segment.source: The name of another dependency property that exists on the type being templated.
segment.target: The name of another dependency property that exists on the type being templated.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: Using TemplateBinding is a fundamental part of how you define a control template, either if you are a custom control author or if you are replacing a control template for existing controls.
segment.target: Using TemplateBinding is a fundamental part of how you define a control template, either if you are a custom control author or if you are replacing a control template for existing controls.

segment.source: For more info, see Quickstart: Control templates.
segment.target: For more info, see Quickstart: Control templates.

segment.source: It's fairly common for propertyName and targetProperty to use the same property name.
segment.target: It's fairly common for propertyName and targetProperty to use the same property name.

segment.source: In this case, a control might define a property on itself and forward the property to an existing and intuitively named property of one of its component parts.
segment.target: In this case, a control might define a property on itself and forward the property to an existing and intuitively named property of one of its component parts.

segment.source: For example, a control that incorporates a TextBlock in its compositing, which is used to display the control's own Text property, might include this XAML as a part in the control template:
segment.target: For example, a control that incorporates a TextBlock in its compositing, which is used to display the control's own Text property, might include this XAML as a part in the control template:

segment.source: The types used as the value for the source property and the target property must match.
segment.target: The types used as the value for the source property and the target property must match.

segment.source: There's no opportunity to introduce a converter when you're using TemplateBinding.
segment.target: There's no opportunity to introduce a converter when you're using TemplateBinding.

segment.source: Failing to match values results in an error when parsing the XAML.
segment.target: Failing to match values results in an error when parsing the XAML.

segment.source: If you need a converter you can use the verbose syntax for a template binding such as:
segment.target: If you need a converter you can use the verbose syntax for a template binding such as:

segment.source: Attempting to use a TemplateBinding outside of a ControlTemplate definition in XAML will result in a parser error.
segment.target: Attempting to use a TemplateBinding outside of a ControlTemplate definition in XAML will result in a parser error.

segment.source: You can use TemplateBinding for cases where the templated parent value is also deferred as another binding.
segment.target: You can use TemplateBinding for cases where the templated parent value is also deferred as another binding.

segment.source: The evaluation for TemplateBinding can wait until any required runtime bindings have values.
segment.target: The evaluation for TemplateBinding can wait until any required runtime bindings have values.

segment.source: A TemplateBinding is always a one-way binding.
segment.target: A TemplateBinding is always a one-way binding.

segment.source: Both properties involved must be dependency properties.
segment.target: Both properties involved must be dependency properties.

segment.source: TemplateBinding is a markup extension.
segment.target: TemplateBinding is a markup extension.

segment.source: Markup extensions are typically implemented when there is a requirement to escape attribute values to be other than literal values or handler names, and the requirement is more global than just putting type converters on certain types or properties.
segment.target: Markup extensions are typically implemented when there is a requirement to escape attribute values to be other than literal values or handler names, and the requirement is more global than just putting type converters on certain types or properties.

segment.source: All markup extensions in XAML use the "{" and "}" characters in their attribute syntax, which is the convention by which a XAML processor recognizes that a markup extension must process the attribute.
segment.target: All markup extensions in XAML use the "{" and "}" characters in their attribute syntax, which is the convention by which a XAML processor recognizes that a markup extension must process the attribute.

segment.source: Note In the Windows Runtime XAML processor implementation, there is no backing class representation for TemplateBinding.
segment.target: Note In the Windows Runtime XAML processor implementation, there is no backing class representation for TemplateBinding.

segment.source: TemplateBinding is exclusively for use in XAML markup.
segment.target: TemplateBinding is exclusively for use in XAML markup.

segment.source: There isn't a straightforward way to reproduce the behavior in code.
segment.target: There isn't a straightforward way to reproduce the behavior in code.
